feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Tornado Warning issued April 2 at 5:04PM EDT until April 2 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
TORRNK
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a
* Tornado Warning for... North central Greenbrier County in southeastern West Virginia...
* Until 530 PM EDT.
* At 503 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado was located near Duo, or 7 miles south of Richwood, moving east at 50 mph.
HAZARD...Tornado.
SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.
IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur. Tree damage is likely.
* Locations impacted include... Leonard... and Beartown State Park.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: TORNADO WARNING in this area til 5:30 PM EDT. Take shelter now. Check media.

National Weather Service: TORNADO WARNING in this area until 5:30 PM EDT. Take shelter now in a basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect yourself from flying debris. Check media.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 2 at 4:04PM CDT until April 2 at 4:30PM CDT by NWS Paducah KY

SVRPAH
The National Weather Service in Paducah has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Central Muhlenberg County in south central Kentucky... Eastern Hopkins County in northwestern Kentucky...

This includes Western Kentucky Parkway between Mile Markers 45 and 65.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 4:56PM EDT until April 3 at 1:09AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
East Branch Brandywine Creek Below Downingtown affecting Chester County.
For the Brandywine Creek...including Downingtown...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...East Branch Brandywine Creek below Downingtown.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 6.0 feet, Open adjacent land next to the creek floods. At 8.0 feet, Dowlin Forge Road begins to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:45 PM EDT Tuesday was 7.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 7.3 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage this evening. Additional rises are expected Wednesday. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.2 feet on 03/01/2021. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 2 at 3:54PM CDT until April 6 at 3:00AM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
entry.summary:
...The Flood Watch continues for the following rivers in Illinois... Wisconsin...
Sugar River At Brodhead affecting Winnebago, Green and Rock Counties.
.Heavy rainfall may result in the Sugar River at Brodhead rising above flood stage by Wednesday morning.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible.
* WHERE...Sugar River at Brodhead.
* WHEN...From late tonight to early Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 6.5 feet, There is widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land. Downstream in the Avon Bottoms area of Rock County, there is flooding in Sugar River Park. Some roads are flooded in Avon Township,including Beloit Newark Rd, about 6 miles downstream of Brodhead. In Illinois, Winslow Rd is threatened near the river between Durand and Shirland. Low lying areas of Sugar Shores Camping Resort may be inundated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM CDT Tuesday the stage was 3.1 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached late tonight. - Flood stage is 5.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Winnebago, IL; Green, WI; Rock, WI

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO EARLY SATURDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 4:52PM EDT until April 4 at 11:30AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Hudson River caused by storm surge and rainfall during times of high tide Wednesday afternoon and particularly early thursday morning.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast New York, including the following counties, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Westchester.
* WHEN...Until 1130 AM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in vulnerable riverfront communities. Expect around 1 to 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in scattered road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses and basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 440 PM EDT, National Weather Service New York NY has issued this Flood Advisory with expectation of flooding along the Hudson River during the times of high tide Wednesday afternoon into Thursday morning, caused by storm surge and rainfall. - In addition rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will exacerbate flooding issues. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Stony Point, Piermont, Cold Spring, Croton On The Hudson, Garrison Landing, Newburgh, Ossining and Cortland. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Orange, NY; Putnam, NY; Rockland, NY; Westchester, NY

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1130 AM EDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 3:51PM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Radar and surface observations show a large area of moderate to heavy snow from central to east-central Wisconsin. Webcams and observer reports indicate that snow is beginning to accumulate on area roadways. Expect roads to become increasingly snow and slush covered and slippery while progressing into the evening commute. Visibility will continue to drop with recently reported visibility less than one-half mile at times in some locations.
Overall, expect a slow and difficult commute due to increasingly snow and slush covered roads. Plan on extra time to reach your destination. Slow down and be sure to increase your following distance as it will take longer to break with these road conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wood; Portage; Waupaca; Outagamie; Brown; Waushara; Winnebago; Calumet

cap:parameter.value: SNOW BEGINNING TO ACCUMULATE ON ROADS FOR THE EVENING COMMUTE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 3:49PM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Illinois...Wisconsin...
Fox River Lower Near New Munster affecting Kenosha and Lake Counties.
.Heavy rainfall will result in the Fox River Lower near New Munster remaining above flood stage until further notice.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Fox River Lower near New Munster.
* WHEN...From this afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 13.8 feet, Floodwaters are into the lower levels of some homes in the Town of Wheatland and Village of Salem Lakes areas along Riverside Drive and Shorewood Drive. This level is the 20 percent chance flood meaning there is a 20 percent chance of the river reaching this level in any given year.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 2 at 4:22PM AST until April 2 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip current conditions due to breaking waves up to 6 to 7 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the northwestern coastline of Puerto Rico from Aguadilla to Hatillo, as well as the northern US Virgin Islands.
* WHEN...Through 6 PM AST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 4:12PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
Conditions are favorable for the development of funnel clouds, which could potentially touch down and become a brief weak tornado. Atmospheric conditions are not favorable for strong, damaging tornadoes. If a tornado were to occur, it would likely be short lived and weak. If threatening weather approaches, seek shelter in an interior room of a sturdy structure.
In addition, winds outside of thunderstorms will briefly gust to 40 to 50 mph in association with a cold front moving through.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Starke; Pulaski; Marshall; Fulton; White; Cass; Northern La Porte; Eastern St. Joseph; Southern La Porte; Western St. Joseph

cap:parameter.value: Funnel Clouds and a Brief Weak Tornado Possible into Early Evening

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...The following counties in Indiana, Dearborn, Fayette, Franklin, Ohio, Ripley, Switzerland, Union and Wayne. The following counties in Kentucky, Boone, Bracken, Campbell, Carroll, Gallatin, Grant, Kenton, Lewis, Mason, Owen, Pendleton and Robertson. * WHEN...Until 11 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Another round of showers and storms are expected through this evening. The potential exists for more heavy rain to fall on wet or saturated soils. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches, with locally higher amounts will be possible.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 2 at 3:06PM CDT until April 3 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW AND STRONG WINDS EXPECTED THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING...
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 8 and 12 inches, with higher amounts to 14 inches possible in far northeast Wisconsin. Lesser accumulations possible near the lakeshore in Kewaunee and Manitowoc counties. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph, causing areas of blowing and drifting snow tonight into Wednesday.
* WHERE...Portions of central, east central, north central, and northeast Wisconsin.
* WHEN...Until 1 PM CDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...The strong winds and weight of snow on tree limbs may down power lines and could cause sporadic power outages. Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning commutes. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 3:05PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary: Conditions are favorable for the development of funnel clouds, which could potentially touch down and become a brief weak tornado. Atmospheric conditions are not favorable for damaging tornadoes. If a tornado were to occur, it would likely be short lived and weak. If threatening weather approaches, seek shelter in an interior room of a sturdy structure.

cap:parameter.value: Funnel Clouds and Brief Weak Tornadoes Possible This Afternoon

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 2 at 3:52PM EDT until April 2 at 9:45PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
FFWPBZ
The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Belmont County in east central Ohio... Carroll County in east central Ohio... Southeastern Columbiana County in east central Ohio... Coshocton County in east central Ohio... Guernsey County in east central Ohio... Harrison County in east central Ohio... Jefferson OH County in east central Ohio... Monroe County in east central Ohio... Muskingum County in east central Ohio... Noble County in east central Ohio... Tuscarawas County in east central Ohio... Brooke County in northern West Virginia... Hancock County in northern West Virginia... Marshall County in northern West Virginia... Ohio County in northern West Virginia... Wetzel County in northern West Virginia...
* Until 945 PM EDT.
* At 352 PM EDT, Morning rainfall of 2.0 to 3.0 inches has caused numerous creeks and streams throughout eastern Ohio and northern West Virginia to flood. Multiple additional rounds of storms are expected during the late afternoon and evening. Imminent additional rainfall up to 1.0 inch is possible in the warned area and could lead to flash flooding.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Wheeling, Zanesville, Weirton, Steubenville, New Philadelphia, Dover, Coshocton, East Liverpool, Cambridge, Moundsville, Martins Ferry, Uhrichsville, New Martinsville, St. Clairsville, Bellaire, Barnesville, Wellsville, Cadiz, Carrollton and Warwood.

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected above 4,000 feet. Total snow accumulations of 4-8 inches above 4,000 feet, with isolated totals of up to 18 inches at the highest elevations. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of central California.
* WHEN...From 11 PM Wednesday to 11 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Strong winds could cause tree damage. The cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 2 at 12:49PM PDT until April 5 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches south of Highway 50. From Interstate 80 to Highway 50, snow accumulations of 5 to 10 inches are expected. Flurries to light accumulations in the upper foothills. Winds gusting up to 45-50 mph.
* WHERE...West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada County, Interstate 80 corridor southward.
* WHEN...From 11 PM Wednesday to 11 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult with slick roads bringing delays and potential chain controls. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Main impacts and highest snow totals Highway 50 southward, including Highways 108, 4, 88, 89. Lingering snow showers expected into early Saturday morning. Snow levels will initially be 6000 to 7000 ft Wednesday evening, before rapidly dropping to 2500-3500 ft by early Thursday morning. Snow levels drop to around 2000 ft briefly Friday morning.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 2 at 3:32PM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet expected. Total snow accumulations up to 7 inches and sleet accumulations around 1 inch. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...In Maine, Coastal York County. In New Hampshire, Coastal Rockingham, Eastern Hillsborough, and Interior Rockingham Counties.
* WHEN...From 2 PM Wednesday to 8 PM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...A snowstorm will bring plowable snow to the region with a period of moderate travel impacts expected. The combination of heavy wet snow and strong winds will lead to snapped branches and downed trees, resulting in power outages. Significant snowfall and periods of heavy snowfall rates will combine with low visibility to create very dangerous driving conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Wednesday evening and Thursday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a expected to be a long-duration, multi-faceted event. While precipitation starts Wednesday, intensity will increase Wednesday night into Thursday when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal York; Eastern Hillsborough; Interior Rockingham; Coastal Rockingham

While precipitation starts Wednesday, intensity will increase Wednesday night into Thursday when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact.

Buck Creek at Acton.

It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 3:23PM EDT until April 3 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, around 1 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. For the Coastal Flood Warning, around 2 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline.
* WHERE...Southern Queens County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 2 PM to 7 PM EDT Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Warning, from 3 AM to 7 AM EDT Thursday.
* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Widespread minor to moderate flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline Wed night. Expect around 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in numerous road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses with basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.
* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 4 to 8 ft Wednesday into Thursday morning, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach flooding and erosion. Scattered areas of dune erosion are possible during the times of high tide Wed afternoon into Thursday morning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain and elevated water levels on Wednesday afternoon into evening may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. The coverage and magnitude of flooding late Wednesday Night will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. This will be refined over the next 24 hours.

* WHERE...In Connecticut, Southern Fairfield and Southern New Haven Counties. In New York, Southern Westchester, Bronx, Northwest Suffolk, Northern Queens and Northern Nassau Counties.
* WHEN...From 4 PM Wednesday to 10 AM EDT Thursday.

* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 3 to 7 ft Wednesday evening, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach erosion with damage to shoreline structures possible. Wave splashover over bulkheads and seawalls will likely exacerbate flooding of shoreline roadways and properties.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain, runoff and elevated water levels Wednesday evening and early Thursday morning may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. * WHEN...From 2 PM Wednesday to noon EDT Thursday.

Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain and elevated water levels on Wednesday afternoon into evening may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 2 at 2:17PM CDT until April 3 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
...Heavy Wet Snow and Strong Winds Impacting Travel Into The Wednesday Morning Commute...
.Narrow, heavy snow bands continue to layout in a north-south orientation across western Wisconsin early this afternoon. 1" per hour rates were common under these bands, with visibilities 1/2 mile or less. Ridge tops and other higher terrain locations have been accumulating the most snow so far today while in valleys snow has collected on cold, grassy surfaces but have left roads wet or slushy.
The snow will continue tonight with narrow snow bands also persisting. Several more inches of accumulation are expected, focused over parts of western and central Wisconsin.
In addition, winds will be on the increase tonight, gusting from 40 to 50 mph. The wet nature of the snow will generally inhibit any significant blowing or drifting, but visibilities will be impacted. Also, there is the potential for any snow laden tree branches or power lines to be brought down.
Travel will be impacted through Wednesday with snow covered to slushy roads and the strong wind gusts. Exercise caution.
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 8 inches. Locally higher possible. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Juneau and Adams Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM CDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning or evening commute.

.Narrow, heavy snow bands continue to layout in a north-south orientation across western Wisconsin early this afternoon. 1" per hour rates were common under these bands, with visibilities 1/2 mile or less. Ridge tops and other higher terrain locations have been accumulating the most snow so far today while in valleys snow has collected on cold, grassy surfaces but have left roads wet or slushy.
The snow will continue tonight with narrow snow bands also persisting. Several more inches of accumulation are expected, focused over parts of western and central Wisconsin.
In addition, winds will be on the increase tonight, gusting from 40 to 50 mph. The wet nature of the snow will generally inhibit any significant blowing or drifting, but visibilities will be impacted. Also, there is the potential for any snow laden tree branches or power lines to be brought down.
Travel will be impacted through Wednesday with snow covered to slushy roads and the strong wind gusts. Exercise caution.
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 8 inches. Locally higher possible. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Monroe, Vernon and Richland Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM CDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning or evening commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 1:33PM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary: Moderate to heavy snow is moving through the area this afternoon, generally along the Interstate 80 corridor and north. 1-3 inches of snow may accumulate, with roads becoming slushy to snow covered, resulting in slick travel conditions this afternoon and evening. Temperatures and roads are a little above freezing, resulting in a wet accumulation on roads, but the higher snowfall rates at times will allow for some accumulation. After 6pm, roads should start to improve, as snowfall rates decrease. Expect lower visibilities in the snow as well, where it may be under a mile at times. Remember, ice and snow, take it slow!

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 2 at 1:59PM EDT until April 4 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northern Delaware, including the following area, New Castle, New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Salem, Somerset, Sussex, Warren and Western Monmouth, and Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Berks, Carbon, Delaware, Eastern Chester, Eastern Montgomery, Lehigh, Lower Bucks, Monroe, Northampton, Philadelphia, Upper Bucks, Western Chester and Western Montgomery.
* WHEN...From Wednesday morning through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Additional rainfall amounts between 1.0 to 3.0 inches are likely across portions of the Watch area through Thursday. About two dozen of our river points are forecast to approach flood stage Wednesday into Thursday, with several exceeding flood stage. The most intense rain is expected to fall Wednesday into Wednesday evening, and with these high rainfall rates, flash flooding cannot be ruled out. Excessive runoff may continue to cause rivers, creeks, and streams to rise through the end of the week even when the rain has ended. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
Keep in mind that our Advanced Hydrologic Prediction System (AHPS), has been updated and upgraded to our new National Water Prediction Service (NWPS). Hydrographs can be found at https://water.noaa.gov

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 2 at 11:24AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
A developing area of rainfall in the Mississippi River Valley is expected to move to the northeast into north central Illinois over the next several hours. Rainfall with rates up to 0.5 inches per hour are likely. Rainfall is expected to continue until changing to snow later this evening. Prior to the changeover to snow, widespread rainfall accumulations up to 1 inch are likely, with localized accumulations near 2 inches possible. Significant rises are possible on area streams and rivers, with rises on larger rivers such as the Pecatonica, Kishwaukee, and Rock continuing for several days. In addition to flooding of rivers, localized flooding of roadways and poor drainage areas is also possible.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Boone, IL; Lee, IL; Ogle, IL; Winnebago, IL

cap:parameter.value: Rainfall may lead to flooding over the next several days

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 11:03AM EDT until April 4 at 10:24PM EDT by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Ohio...
Scioto River Near Larue affecting Marion County.
Killbuck Creek Near Killbuck affecting Wayne and Holmes Counties.
For the Scioto River...including Larue, Prospect...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Killbuck Creek...including Killbuck...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Scioto River near Larue.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to late Thursday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Flooding occurs in agricultural areas near the river. At 12.0 feet, Flooding occurs in lowland areas south of the Village of La Rue. Roads inundated include High Street, Larue Prospect Road, and parts of Vine Street. At 13.0 feet, River at bankfull in the Village of La Rue. Widespread flooding on area roads including School Street. At 14.0 feet, River out of banks in La Rue. Water will spread into Front Street and East School Street. Access in and out of La Rue cut off in Several areas. At 14.5 feet, Major flood losses in the Village of La Rue expected. Many roads become inundated. Floodwaters effectively surround the town. The river will flood portions of northern La Rue which will affect lower areas in the center of the city. Southern portions of the town also affected. Several access roads inundated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 13.1 feet tomorrow morning. entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 10:09AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Gilchrist and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.noaa.gov
The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 1015 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 16.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight and continue rising to 17.8 feet Sunday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

In west central Indiana, Clay, Owen, Parke, Putnam, Vermillion and Vigo.

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 2 at 3:34AM HST until April 4 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 6 PM HST THURSDAY OVER WINDIER AREAS ACROSS THE STATE...
.A strong high pressure system will continue to build in north of the Hawaiian Islands through Thursday. Strong and gusty easterly trade winds will exceed wind advisory thresholds in windier areas across the state.
* WHAT...Trade winds 25 to 35 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph expected.
* WHERE...Portions of Kahoolawe, Kauai, Lanai, Maui, Molokai, Oahu and the Big Island.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 6 PM HST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Winds this strong can tear off shingles, knock down tree branches, blow away tents and awnings and make it difficult to steer, especially for drivers of high profile vehicles.

entry.title: Child Abduction Emergency issued April 2 at 8:29AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
CAESPN
El siguiente mensaje se transmite a solicitud del Departamento de Policia de Puerto Rico en San Juan, Puerto Rico.
El Departamento de Policia de Puerto Rico busca a JADEISHKA RIVERA VAZQUEZ. Fue vista por ultima vez en la urbanizacion Lomas Verdes en Bayamon. Vestia una chaqueta de mahon, pantalon corto y tenis color rosa. Tiene 13 anos, piel blanca, cabello negro, ojos marrones, mide 5 pies y una pulgada de alto y pesa 125 libras.
Si tiene alguna informacion sobre su paradero, favor de comunicarse al 787-343-2020 o al 9-1-1.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 5:23AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV late Wednesday through Thursday and bring gusty winds, much colder temperatures and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop Wednesday afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395 and I-580.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra Wednesday and spread across the region Wednesday night through Friday. Several inches of accumulating snow will bring periods of slick and snow covered roads to the Sierra and foothills, especially during the nighttime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel through the Sierra.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

cap:parameter.value: ANOTHER PROLONGED PERIOD OF COLD AND UNSETTLED WEATHER AHEAD

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 7:23AM EDT until April 4 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Advisory is extended for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Ohio River At Pittsburgh affecting Allegheny County.
.An intense storm system moving eastward toward the region has produced widespread light to moderate rainfall over the Monongahela River basin. These rains are causing rapid rises at the Ohio river at Pittsburgh to rise steadily. Additional rainfall is forecast for the next 12 to 18 hours that will cause the Ohio River to rise above 18.0 feet, flooding the Monongahela River Parking Wharf.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...Until early Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 17.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 18.5 feet early tomorrow afternoon. - Action stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 3 feet along the coast from the starting Wednesday night. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

cap:parameter.value: Strong Storm Causing Water To Move Onto Near Shore Ice Wednesday Night

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north across the Bering Sea on Tuesday and Wednesday will bring water levels up 3 to 4 feet along the coast from the Bering Strait south on Wednesday and Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for most of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Strong Storm Causing Water To Move Onto Near Shore Ice Wednesday

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 2 at 4:06AM CDT until April 2 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts in excess of 45 mph.
* WHERE...Champaign, Clark, Coles, Cumberland, Douglas, Edgar, and Vermilion Counties.
* WHEN...From noon today to 8 PM CDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Champaign; Vermilion; Douglas; Coles; Edgar; Cumberland; Clark

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO 8 PM CDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 2 at 12:48AM AKDT until April 2 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Northwest winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph expected. Reduced visibility at times due to falling and blowing snow.
* WHERE...Upper Tanana Valley including Tok and Northway.
* WHEN...From 6 AM to 7 PM AKDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM THIS MORNING TO 7 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 2 at 12:46AM AKDT until April 4 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and blowing snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches possible. Visibility below one half mile at times.
* WHERE...Point Hope.
* WHEN...From late tonight through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on hazardous travel conditions. The cold wind chills as low as 30 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH NOW IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 2 at 3:59AM EDT until April 4 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Walton, Bay, Gulf, and Franklin County Beaches.
* WHEN...Through late Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Walton; Coastal Bay; Coastal Gulf; Coastal Franklin

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT
